commit.message:
Fix wrong precedence of 'expr | getline' expressions (#216)

This pull request modifies `getLine()` inside parser.go so that it lets
binary operators come after 'expr | getline' expressions.

I also uncommented two tests that were in TODO inside interp_test.go
and added two new tests.

There were two other tests under the same TODO: (`BEGIN { print("echo foo" | getline ($0+1)); print }` and `BEGIN { print("echo foo" | getline foo()); print } function foo() { print "z" }`), but those address a separate issue.

parent e206313ce4de46ddf6f9720ed14c88dea1d58211
author Andrea Fiori <47670182+fioriandrea@users.noreply.github.com> 1711352208 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1711352208 +0000

Fix wrong precedence of 'expr | getline' expressions (#216)

This pull request modifies `getLine()` inside parser.go so that it lets

I also uncommented two tests that were in TODO inside interp_test.go
and added two new tests.

There were two other tests under the same TODO: (`BEGIN { print("echo foo" | getline ($0+1)); print }` and `BEGIN { print("echo foo" | getline foo()); print } function foo() { print "z" }`), but those address a separate issue.

commit.message: Fix README CI badge link (so *that's* why it was failing)

Fix a few minor things staticcheck found (#224)

* Check interp.New error return (even though it's always nil now)

* Use strings.Contains where possible

* Remove unnecessary return in topoSort helper

* Remove a couple of unnecessary clauses/comments

* Rename doubleCloseError to more idiomatic errDoubleClose

* Don't run main tests with Gawk's --posix flag

We weren't actually anyway, as args wasn't being used.

No there are no errors with the following command:

    staticcheck -checks=inherit,-ST1001 ./...

ST1001 is "should not use dot imports".

commit.message:
Fix issue #79: Incorrect parsing of complex ++ expressions (#215)

Fix incorrect parsing and compiling of complex ++ expressions.
Needed to add a new Rote opcode to make this happen.
In addition, fix similar evaluation issues with += and sub/gsub.
Add new regression tests for all of the above.

tree cf6b30313e447e56ba0ef3af305f838e804d3713

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1697742200 +0100

Fix issue #79: Incorrect parsing of complex ++ expressions (#215)

Fix incorrect parsing and compiling of complex ++ expressions.
Needed to add a new Rote opcode to make this happen.
In addition, fix similar evaluation issues with += and sub/gsub.
Add new regression tests for all of the above.

commit.message:
Fix #190: FS regex [^,]* fails on empty field (#214)

A custom split function has been introduced. This split function skips
empty matches. It is used only for FS.

See https://github.com/benhoyt/goawk/issues/190 for details

commit.message:
Fix rare race in pipe-to-command close() result test (#213)

The bufio.Writer does not write to the Cmd pipe until Flush is
called when the Cmd is Wait-ed on. This causes a Flush error but
not a Wait error. This only happens if the Cmd starts and exits
before the Flush can be called by goawk.

Fix this by forcing the spawned "sh" command to read a line of
input before exiting or sending a signal to itself.

Automated tests ran into another problem:

The windows GitHub runner installs gawk using Chocolatey and this
package of gawk does not use "sh" to execute commands, instead it
uses "cmd.exe". Because "read" is a "sh" builtin command this will
not work for windows tests of gawk and probably other awks.

verification.payload:
tree 6b9bf18c681b1bb89f00c60d40ec034d3250bd4f
parent 5311ab15ac2b0ad716306adfc3e873c3fe6bf164
author Justin Davis <juster@users.noreply.github.com> 1697436564 -0400
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1697436564 +0100

Fix rare race in pipe-to-command close() result test (#213)

The bufio.Writer does not write to the Cmd pipe until Flush is
called when the Cmd is Wait-ed on. This causes a Flush error but
not a Wait error. This only happens if the Cmd starts and exits
before the Flush can be called by goawk.

Fix this by forcing the spawned "sh" command to read a line of
input before exiting or sending a signal to itself.

Automated tests ran into another problem:

The windows GitHub runner installs gawk using Chocolatey and this
package of gawk does not use "sh" to execute commands, instead it
uses "cmd.exe". Because "read" is a "sh" builtin command this will
not work for windows tests of gawk and probably other awks.

commit.message:
Build with PGO - it's more than 5% faster

We can probably get a more realistic PGO profile than just running the
microbenchmarks, but it'll do.

goawk=go1.21.0 with PGO
orig =go1.21.0 without PGO

Test                         |    goawk |     orig |      awk
---------------------------- | -------- | -------- | --------
tt.01 (print)                |     3.02 |     2.76 |     1.00
tt.02 (print NR NF)          |     2.07 |     1.95 |     1.00
tt.02a (print length)        |     1.85 |     1.80 |     1.00
tt.03 (sum length)           |     1.53 |     1.47 |     1.00
tt.03a (sum field)           |     1.47 |     1.44 |     1.00
tt.04 (printf fields)        |     1.36 |     1.21 |     1.00
tt.05 (concat fields)        |     1.54 |     1.48 |     1.00
tt.06 (count lengths)        |     1.64 |     1.55 |     1.00
tt.07 (even fields)          |     1.49 |     1.43 |     1.00
tt.08 (even lengths)         |     2.54 |     2.60 |     1.00
tt.08z (regex simple)        |     3.73 |     3.71 |     1.00
tt.09 (regex starts with)    |     2.87 |     2.83 |     1.00
tt.10 (regex ends with)      |     0.47 |     0.45 |     1.00
tt.10a (regex ends with var) |     0.45 |     0.44 |     1.00
tt.11 (substr)               |     3.35 |     3.16 |     1.00
tt.12 (update fields)        |     1.53 |     1.51 |     1.00
tt.13 (array ops)            |     4.84 |     4.28 |     1.00
tt.13a (array printf)        |     3.03 |     2.83 |     1.00
tt.14 (function call)        |     1.73 |     1.50 |     1.00
tt.15 (format lines)         |     1.00 |     0.97 |     1.00
tt.16 (count words)          |     1.92 |     1.77 |     1.00
tt.big (complex program)     |     2.29 |     2.17 |     1.00
tt.x1 (mandelbrot)           |     2.68 |     2.67 |     1.00
tt.x2 (sum loop)             |     2.41 |     2.19 |     1.00
---------------------------- | -------- | -------- | --------
**Geo mean**                 | **1.86** | **1.76** | **1.00**

Add support for new Unicode string escape \u (#212)

Allows 1-8 hex digits after the "\u".

See similar onetrueawk and Gawk changes:
- https://github.com/onetrueawk/awk/commit/ac3084de9b64d0c838e520ea1ebdb2e1bde87b3f
- https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gawk.git/commit/?id=1bc73bfb10f0600aaccca7220b5200e220f9a71a

Also, in lexer tests, stop after first error.

Fixes #210

tree 28cded8fd45736f22a0767221395c13c472fbab9
parent 17fbb8bf2380ac2eac7593bea67cdfa71fd5d729
author Ben Hoyt <benhoyt@gmail.com> 1695687785 +1300
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1695687785 +0100

commit.message:
Parse interpTest flags and implement "!windows" flag

The !windows flag will cause both the external awk tests and the goawk tests
to be skipped if the tests are running on Windows.

Signal-based test cases were failing on windows for goawk because Windows
does not support POSIX signals. These are simulated on cygwin which is
what MSYS2 appears to be using. MSYS2 is preinstalled on the Windows image
which the CI runs.

My best guess is that the MSYS2 kill command is forcing the child process to
terminate with (signal << 8) as the exit status.

Additionally, the gawk in the Windows CI image is using cmd.exe and not sh.
Naturally, there are no exec or kill commands available from cmd.exe.

Ironically, the signal exit status behaves predictibly for gawk on cygwin.

Stricter flag parsing exposed some interpTest entries that were missing
a comment char ('#').

Adds iostream_test.go to test iostream in interp

There is not much to test. The only important one I could think of
was consistent behavior in the event of a double-close.

Modify existing tests to check child processes

Enable gawk tests "status-close" and "sigpipe1". "sigpipe1" is
skipped on Windows because it relies on the SIGPIPE POSIX signal.

Modify TestShellCommand to check interpreter exit after missing shell

Adds some interpTests entries to check signal exit from system().
Also adds entries to check signal exit and normal exit from a piped
command close().

Make system() result identical to close(pipe) result

Old behavior always returned -1 on a signal exit.

Fixes #205

Define I/O streams to abstract pipe/file access & closing

Creates the iostream.go file and uses I/O stream interfaces for all
file redirects and command pipes. Defines inputStream and outputStream
interfaces which satisfy the io.ReadCloser and io.WriteCloser
interfaces, respectively. Adds an additional .ExitCode() accessor
to return the exit code for goawk's close() builtin function.

When the argument to close() is a pipe, this mimicks gawk's behavior:

1. The value passed to exit() when process exits normally
2. 256 + signal code when process exits due to signal
3. 512 + signal code when process exits due to signal with a core dump

Fixes #203
Fixes #204
More direct explanation for --csv in goawk help (#211)

verification.payload:
tree ba07aea32ce1a7a3fa72eabae7a83d909476ce81
parent 1398e2df55d55d4ee7024355d3f4cc20d5166d8a
author Ben Hoyt <benhoyt@gmail.com> 1694381765 +1200
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1694381765 +0100

More direct explanation for --csv in goawk help (#211)

commit.message:
flushAll() stops flushing on first error (#209)

The && operator causes conditional evaluation (aka "short-circuiting").
This means if the left-hand-side is false the right hand side is
not evaluated. If any call to interp.flushWriter returns false then
all streams following that stream in the range, as well as
interp.output, will not be flushed.

Removes the type cast to the flusher interface because that is done
in interp.flushWriter. This check would be performed twice for any
interp.output value whose type implements the interface.

Fixes #208

verification.payload:
tree 94b2994dd00b6f084bba348d075111fe8c12ed84
parent f2d5f1f1f831a193901126379d9401949d5f6185
author Justin Davis <juster@users.noreply.github.com> 1694381531 -0400
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1694381531 +0100

The && operator causes conditional evaluation (aka "short-circuiting").
This means if the left-hand-side is false the right hand side is
not evaluated. If any call to interp.flushWriter returns false then
all streams following that stream in the range, as well as
interp.output, will not be flushed.

Removes the type cast to the flusher interface because that is done

interp.output value whose type implements the interface.

commit.message:
Make two-argument split() respect CSV input mode (#198)

This is how awk and gawk's upcoming --csv feature works, so we want to
be consistent. Note that it is a breaking change (hopefully a minor
one, and only applies to people using CSV input mode).

tree 48faaa7135c8203e25bd95870303de27ae27b445

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1689331729 +0100

Make two-argument split() respect CSV input mode (#198)

This is how awk and gawk's upcoming --csv feature works, so we want to
be consistent. Note that it is a breaking change (hopefully a minor
one, and only applies to people using CSV input mode).

commit.message: Bump up patch version for v1.23.3 release

Reintroduce additional resolve passes to fix complex mutual recursion (#187)

Not exactly an elegant solution, but does the job and fixes
the problem with resolving mutually-recursive functions.

Historical note: prior to introducing topological sorting this was
the only way the type resolver did it, regardless of call graph.
See https://github.com/benhoyt/goawk/commit/0bc9499481ee7775f1cc5fcca3bcac1443811bf4.

Fixes #186

verification.payload:
tree a6a2ee9ef6baea5aa05f2f0e02bfa524d2a8d7b4
parent d1e11be8f0e3a131d8563447fd97496f48abe8e0
author Ben Hoyt <benhoyt@gmail.com> 1686468356 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1686468356 +0100

Reintroduce additional resolve passes to fix complex mutual recursion (#187)

Not exactly an elegant solution, but does the job and fixes
the problem with resolving mutually-recursive functions.

Historical note: prior to introducing topological sorting this was
the only way the type resolver did it, regardless of call graph.
See https://github.com/benhoyt/goawk/commit/0bc9499481ee7775f1cc5fcca3bcac1443811bf4.

Fixes #186

commit.message:
Add tests that require topoSort (#185)

Per https://github.com/benhoyt/goawk/issues/183#issuecomment-1576732599,
and given the two passes we do, the current test suite doesn't have
any tests which require topoSort (topological sort of functions based
on the call graph). Add a couple of these tests in case of
regressions.

If you comment out the `topoSort` call, these tests fail with
something like:

```
$ go run . -f t.awk
panic: internal error: found scalar when expecting array "c" [recovered]
	panic: interface conversion: interface {} is string, not *compiler.compileError [recovered]
	panic: interface conversion: interface {} is *runtime.TypeAssertionError, not *ast.PositionError
...
$ cat t.awk
function f1(a) { f2(a) }
function f2(b) { f3(b) }
function f3(c) { f4(c) }
function f4(d) { f5(d) }
function f5(i) { i[1]=42 }
BEGIN { x[1]=3; f5(x); print x[1] }
```

verification.payload:
tree 2215d8eb98948194ea9a95d7a19358b73b555c14
parent 92e079972bb76535f72002fad2b58c812de76b24
author Ben Hoyt <benhoyt@gmail.com> 1686213024 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1686213024 +0100
